bill_title: provide that certain building permits contain statements concerning liens, lien waivers, and potential financial liability.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to prohibit suppliers from seeking recourse against a homeowner if the homeowner has paid the contractor. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. If a person has a realty improvement contract with a contractor for a single-family residential structure and the person has paid the contractor pursuant to such contract, no supplier to the contractor may seek recourse against the person for nonpayment for any materials supplied for the realty improvement. 350 copies of this document were printed by the South Dakota Legislative Research Council at a cost of $.027 per page. . Insertions into existing statutes are indicated by underscores. Deletions from existing statutes are indicated by overstrikes.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to prohibit suppliers from seeking recourse against a homeowner if the homeowner has paid the contractor. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. No unit of local government may issue a building permit unless it has received as part of the building permit application process a certificate signed by the owner of the property to which the building permit relates. This certificate shall state that the property owner understands that: (1) The failure of a prime contractor or subcontractor to pay those persons supplying materials or services to complete the improvement for which the building permit is sought can result in the filing of a lien; (2) To avoid this result, when paying for labor and materials, the property owner may ask the prime contractor or subcontractor for lien waivers from all persons supplying materials or services for the work described in the permit; and (3) Failure to secure lien waivers may result in the property's owner paying for labor and materials twice.
